messageBody:
The apostrophe is generally not used to mark plurals in Quikscript or Shavian because they're phonetically and phonemically identical to possessives. But for contractions, where words are shortened and connected, they're usually retained.
As for that accent, I don't have a copy of the Quikscript manual on hand--I know I saved it somewhere--but isn't it just a short vertical line or dot? If so, then there is a combining character for it in Unicode. The character "COMBINING VERTICAL LINE ABOVE" at the codepoint 030D, and the "COMBINING DOT ABOVE" is 0307. Neither is specific to any script, so it should be fine to use them with Quikscript. Here are both of them on the letter o for reference: o̍ ȯ

Those may not display correctly. Using Thunderbird on my Mac, only the first one does. Assuming you've got decent Unicode support, it's functionality will depend mostly on the font you're using. So as long as your Quikscript font has the character in a working state, it should display correctly.

However, I don't think setting Senior Quikscript on a computer will be that difficult. It's pretty easy with Opentype, among others, to automate selection of alternates and ligatures. It would be more work for the designer (I've considered taking on the task myself), but none at all for the user. In the Latin alphabet, for example, it's customary to replace certain groups of letters with ligatures to make them fit more neatly together. Lowercase "fi" and "fl" will be replaced automatically, if the software supports it, with the ligatures "ﬁ" and "ﬂ". Some fonts provide even more including "ff", "fj", "fk" etc., as well as many with a long s instead of f. This kind of replacement is used extensively in Arabic because of its cursive nature and works perfectly without any user input. You just have to know what sequences of letters require what contextual replacements. That's where it seems to get a bit complicated when you have to account for pairs and triplets and so on such that "anl" gets replaced with "uGl", but not after another letter that connects on top. But that's as complicated as it gets. And it's not as bad as it sounds: some of this can be simplified by grouping characters into classes according to how they connect on each side. Then replacements can be done automatically for each class so that everything runs together. If we give them plain-English names (I don't know about other systems, but OpenType generally assigns them numbers), we could call them "top-top", "top-bottom", "bottom-top", and "bottom-bottom". Then write replacements to make sure tops and bottoms go together.

Now, getting software to support these features is another matter. It's just not quite there yet.
 
Regards,
Joseph Spicer
JOsaf spFsD

The apostrophy works well in T.O. to show the difference between

each word.
